content: Some Code Examples library ieee; use ieee.std_logic_1164.all; use ieee.numeric_std.all; entity top is port ( clk : in std_logic; rst_n : in std_logic; segments : out std_logic_vector(6 downto 0); digit_sel : out std_logic ); end top; architecture rtl of top is begin segments <= (others => '0'); end architecture; #include <iostream> int main(int argc, char* argv[]) { std::cout << "Hello, world!" << std::endl; } import numpy as np def main() : print("Hello, world!") if __name__ == "__main__" : main() fn main(){println!("Hello, world!");}

content: Mathematical Formula The information entropy, $ H $, over a discrete data is given as, $$ H = - \sum_i p_i \cdot log_2 (p_i), $$ where the $ p_i $ are the probabilities of codes/states, indexed by $ i $, in the data. When considering a continuous distribution, interpreted as a probability distribution function that satisfies $ \int_{-\inf}^{+\inf} p(x) dx = 1$, the information entropy is given by, $$ H(x) = - \int_{-\inf}^{+\inf} p(x) \cdot log_2[p(x)] dx. $$
